edition.glossary-entry:
αἴθυια(aithyia). A poetic word, of uncertain or indefinite meaning.
Probably a large Gull,
e.g. Larus marinus, the Black-backed Gull , Sundevall , rare in Greece or
L. argentatus, the Herring Gull Krüper , the former being rare in Greece.
abundant during the winter and breeds about the middle of April
Netolicka 's hypothesis of the Merganser
Do not tally with Aristotle Historia Animalium 5. 9, 542b
and that of
Groshans that it was a Diver or
do not tally with Aristotle Historia Animalium 5. 9, 542b:
Grebe,
do not tally with Aristotle Historia Animalium 5. 9, 542b:
Schneider 's identification with Skua, Lestris Parasiticus
fails inasmuch as the latter does not dive (vide Buchholz, op.cit. pp. 112, 113)
nor does it breed in the Mediterranean .
The Herring Gull is abundant during the winter and breeds about the middle of April:
the Common Tern (Sterna anglica)
lays about the same time as the Herring gull ( Krüper ) but in the lagoons and not on the cliffs .
Od.Odyssey v. 337, 3535. 337 and 353. http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc1:1.1-1.43
Arist. Aristotle H.A.Historia Animalium v. 9, 542b5. 9. 542b "The aithyia, or diver, and the larus, or gull, lay their eggs on rocks bordering on the sea, two or three at a time; but the gull lays in the summer, and the diver at the beginning of spring, just after the winter solstice, and it broods over its eggs as birds do in general. And neither of these birds resorts to a hiding-place." (ἡ δʼ αἴθυια καὶ οἱ λάροι τίκτουσι μέν ἐν ταῖς περὶ θάλατταν πέτραις, τὸ μέν πλῆθος δύο ἢ τρία· ἀλλʼ ὁ μέν λάρος τοῦ θέρους, ἡ δʼ αἴθυια ἀρχομένου τοῦ ἔαρος...)
[cf. Mergus,
Plin.Pliny Naturalis Historia 10. 32 (48)] εὐθὺς ἐκ τροπῶν. οὐδέτερον δέ φωλεύει. Also idem 1. 487;8.3, 593 b.
Αrrian, Peripl. Periplus ed. Didot, 1855, i. p. 395, names it with λάροι and κορῶναι αἱ θαλάσσιοι
, and
Hesych.Hesychius Lexicon aithyia renders aἴθυιαι by εἰνάλιαι κορῶναι . Frequent in the
Gk. Anthol. e.g. Glauc. vi, vol. iii. p. 58; Marc. Arg.xxxi,ibid. ii. p. 250; Callim.xci; Leon. Tar.xci; Gk. Anthol. i. p. 178; Anon. ibid. iv. p. 143
Greek Anthology; e.g. 6.23
Greek Anthology Mnasalcas 7.212
Greek Anthology 7.285 ὄλετο γὰρ σὺν νηὶ, τὰ δʼ ὁστέα ποῦ ποτʼ ἐκείνου πύθεται, αἰθυίαις γνωστὰ μόναις ἐνέπειν, cf.
Greek Anthology 7.374
Greek Anthology 10.8
Phile.Philemon, De Anim.De Animalibus Pr. 68o, is hostile to πελαργός and κρέξ.
Is said to be deaf and dumb, Aristoph.Aristophanes Hist. Anim. Epit.Historia Animalium Epitome i. 141.
The metamorphosis of Hyperippa, daughter of Munychus, Νicander ap. Anton. Lib.Nicander in Antoninus Liberalis Met.Metamorphoses 14.
Αrat. Aratus Phen.Phaenomena 918, a sign of rain; πολλάκις δʼἀγριάδες νῆσσαι εἰναλίδιναι οἴθυιαι χερσαῖα τινάσσονται ππrερύγεσσιν:
cf Theophr. Theophrastus De Sign.De Signibus ii. 282.28, a sign of rain
Virg.Virgil Georg.Georgics i.3621.362.
Α lοng but unsatisfactory description in Dion.Dionysius De Avib.De Avibus ii.52.5.
Α title or epithet of Athene, Paus.Pausanias 1.5.3 , 1.41.6.
Said to be the name of a horse in Mnasalc. Mnasalcas xiii.Gk. Anthol. i. p. 125.7.212
See also δύππτης, λάρoς.
